World Leaders Declare Common Values and Goals World leaders at the United Nations Millennium Summit issued a declaration that sought to balance the developed world's interest in pursuing universal democracy, the rule of law and human rights, including the equality of women, with demands by poor nations for better balance in the world economy and more benefits from the rise of globalization.

President Clinton urged China's president, Jiang Zemin, to open a dialogue with the new government of Taiwan and to put a stop to China's missile exports to Pakistan. But Mr. Jiang offered little more than cordial good wishes for Mr. Clinton's retirement from office and gratitude for his support of China's bid to join the World Trade Organization.

The Security Council condemned the killings of three United Nations refugee workers in West Timor on Wednesday and insisted that the Indonesian government take immediate steps to disarm and disband the militias believed responsible.

Cuban Leader on the West Side President Fidel Castro denounced the American economic embargo against his country and presented a bleak vision of the world's future before thousands of cheering and flag-waving supporters gathered at Riverside Church in Manhattan.

End to Austria Sanctions Urged A panel appointed by the European Union to assess human rights and political life in Austria reported that minorities, refugees and immigrants enjoy as many or more rights and protections there as their counterparts elsewhere in the 15-member European Union. The findings clear the way for the European Union to lift diplomatic sanctions hurriedly imposed after a far-right party joined Austria's government.

Push for Naval Aid Agreement President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has begun consultations with other leaders on an international agreement in which nations that operate warships under the sea would come to one another's aid during disasters. The initiative follows Russia's loss of the nuclear submarine Kursk and its 118-member crew last month.

Bush Yields on Debates And Will Seek Compromise Gov. George W. Bush abandoned his effort to impose his own schedule of presidential debates, and his campaign said it was prepared to sit down with aides to Vice President Al Gore to work out an agreement for debating under the auspices of a bipartisan commission.

Mr. Bush held a sustained question-and-answer session with voters for the first time since the primary campaign. The Republican National Committee unveiled its harshest ad yet against Mr. Gore, in a drive to cast doubt on his credibility.

Lieberman in Texas Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, campaigning in Gov. George W. Bush's state, painted a dismal picture of the Bush record on child health care and said Mr. Bush could not be trusted with the issue on a national scale.
Retreat on Medicare Cuts The Clinton administration indefinitely deferred plans to cut Medicare payments for cancer drugs given to hundreds of thousands of patients.

Official Apology to Indians The head of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, in a ceremony for the agency's 175th anniversary, apologized ''for what the agency has done in the past,'' including aiding in ''ethnic cleansing.'' The official, Kevin Gover, is a member of the Pawnee Tribe.

Auto Pollution Rules Kept California regulators rejected pleas from the automobile industry and resolved to maintain a rule requiring that 10 percent of cars offered for sale in the state starting in 2003 emit little or no pollution. The action is expected to lead to a vast increase in the number of electric cars on the road, not only in California but in New York, Massachusetts, Vermont and Maine, which have chosen to follow California pollution rules.

Sentencing of Repeat Offenders The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether federal prisoners can seek federal court review when prior state convictions are the reason a prisoner has been sentenced to extra time as a repeat offender.

New Police Commissioner Shifting 300 to Patrols The new police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, plans to move at least 300 officers from quality-of-life enforcement to street patrols as part of a larger reassignment that will also beef up the city's overburdened detective squads, officials said.

Financier Is Sued by Mother Anne Steinberg, 83, mother of Saul P. Steinberg, the founder of Reliance Group Holdings, whose once-lavish lifestyle has taken a downturn, is suing her son, saying he and his brother, Robert, owe her millions.

Gloom in Nassau County Offices Democratic and Republican officials alike said the county's fiscal troubles were so deep that it was now a distinct possibility -- perhaps a likelihood -- that the state would take over the county's finances.

Bone Loss in AIDS Patients An uncommon bone-destroying disorder, osteonecrosis, also called avascular necrosis, is turning up with surprising frequency among people with the virus that causes AIDS, federal researchers said.

A Williams Makes the Finals Venus Williams defeated Martina Hingis, 4-6, 6-3, 7-5, to advance to the finals where she will meet Lindsay Davenport, who beat Elena Dementieva, 6-2, 7-6 (5). The Open title is currently held by Williams's sister, Serena, who was eliminated.

Indiana Coach Denies Abuse Bobby Knight denied an allegation that he had physically and verbally assaulted a student who addressed him by his last name. An investigation of the basketball coach's previous conduct led the university to impose on him a ''zero tolerance'' policy toward misbehavior.

Initiative on Auto Safety The head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said she would ask Congress for additional money and new authority to ferret out safety problems like the ones that have plagued Firestone tires.

Mitsubishi Motors Chief Quits Katsuhiko Kawasoe resigned as president, and Rolf Eckrodt, chief executive of DaimlerChrysler's trainmaking subsidiary, will become Mitsubishi's new chief operating officer. The moves came as DaimlerChrysler tightened control over Mitsubishi, which is reeling from disclosures that it long concealed customer complaints about defects.

Wal-Mart Told to Raise Prices German competition regulators ordered the giant retailer to raise its prices for household staples like milk, flour, butter, rice and cooking oil in its German stores. Germany's federal cartel office accused Wal-Mart of inciting a price war in which it and two German supermarket chains illegally sold products below their wholesale costs to devastate smaller stores.
Technology Stocks Slide The Nasdaq dropped 119.94 points, or 2.9 percent, to 3,978.41; the Dow lost 39.22 points, to 11,220.65; and the S.& P. 500 fell 8.01, to 1,494.50.
